expectations:
- MUST be in US English (teaching French)
      - Should cover French-specific grammar (gender/articles, subjunctive, past tenses, etc.)
      - Should cover vocabulary themes for everyday French situations (food, travel, etc.)
      - Should cover communication scenarios (greetings, shopping, etc.)

      
  - Chapters should follow CEFR progression from A1 (beginner) to C2 (mastery)
  - ALL chapters must be content-domain chapters: grammar structures, vocabulary themes, or communication scenarios
  - NO skill-based chapters (pronunciation, listening, reading, writing) — those skills are built into every lesson automatically
  - NO culture chapters (history, traditions, cuisine, music, festivals, customs)
  - NO career or professional chapters (business language, workplace communication)
  - NO proficiency exam preparation chapters (DELE, JLPT, DELF, HSK, etc.)
  - NO literature or media chapters (books, films, songs, poetry)
  - Should cover grammar structures (verb tenses, nouns, articles, etc.) and vocabulary themes (food, travel, health, etc.)
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Titles should be concise, no filler words
  - Descriptions should be concise, no fluff (avoid "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.)
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises

rankings.reasoning: Model D produces 91 chapters with excellent granularity and CEFR progression from A1 to C2. It follows almost all prompt rules: no skill-based chapters, no culture/literature/exam prep chapters. Grammar is broken into fine-grained chapters (separate chapters for direct vs indirect object pronouns, passé composé with avoir vs être, multiple subjunctive chapters, relative clause progression, etc.). Vocabulary themes are well-covered (food, shopping, health, weather, travel, home, education, technology, environment). Communication scenarios are present (greetings, requests, directions, phone calls, etc.). The interleaving of grammar and vocabulary is well done. It includes good advanced/C2 content (literary past tenses, reduced clauses, pragmatic nuance, wordplay & ambiguity, conversation management, regional variation). Descriptions are concise and on-point, avoiding fluff words like 'learn' or 'explore'. One minor concern: 'Work & Occupations' could be seen as borderline career/professional, but as vocabulary it's standard and the prompt only forbids 'career/professional chapters' like business language and workplace communication, whereas basic job/occupation vocabulary is a standard vocabulary theme mentioned in the prompt itself. The chapter 'High-Precision Grammar Review' has 'review' in the name which could be seen as assessment-adjacent, but it's really about stabilizing accuracy. Overall, this is an exceptionally thorough and well-organized curriculum.

Model E has 91 chapters with very thorough coverage from A1 to C2. It covers all major grammar structures with appropriate granularity (separate -er, -ir/-re verb chapters, passé composé split by auxiliary, multiple subjunctive chapters, etc.). Vocabulary themes are comprehensive (food, home, health, weather, travel, shopping, technology, environment, emotions). Communication scenarios are present. The progression is logical and well-ordered. Descriptions are generally concise. However, there are some concerns: 'News & Media Language' could be seen as a media chapter (explicitly forbidden), though it's more about vocabulary than media analysis. 'Formal Writing & Correspondence' is somewhat skill-based (writing), which is built into every lesson. 'Work & Occupations' is borderline but acceptable as vocabulary. 'Specialized & Technical Vocabulary' is vague. 'Regional Variations of French' borders on culture. Some descriptions use 'building' which is mildly filler-ish. Overall very strong but a few borderline violations.

Model B has 63 chapters with good coverage and logical progression. Grammar is well-covered with appropriate granularity (relative clauses split into core/advanced, subjunctive split, conditional split, etc.). Vocabulary themes are covered though somewhat fewer dedicated vocabulary chapters compared to top models. The interleaving is good. Descriptions are concise and well-written. However, several chapters are problematic: 'Near-Native Fluency' as a final chapter is vague and feels like a capstone. 'Style & Naturalness' and 'Ambiguity & Reformulation' are somewhat abstract and skill-oriented. 'Accuracy: High-Frequency Errors' reads like an assessment/review chapter. 'Paraphrase & Synthesis' is somewhat skill-based. Some C2-level chapters are quite abstract. Missing some vocabulary domains that other models cover (work/occupations is absent, money/banking absent). No dedicated chapter for hobbies/sports until later. Overall solid but with some gaps and borderline chapters.

Model C has 59 chapters with decent coverage. Grammar is well-structured with good granularity. However, there are some issues: 'Formal Correspondence & Official Formulas' is borderline skill-based (writing). 'Spoken Fluency, Interaction & Spontaneity' is skill-based (speaking/listening). 'Mastery Grammar & Rare Constructions' is vague. 'Colloquial Speech & Regional Variants' partially touches culture. The vocabulary themes are somewhat fewer and placed late in the curriculum (Food & Dining at chapter 36, Shopping at 37, Travel at 38), which is unusual - these are typically A1-B1 topics but appear after advanced grammar. This ordering issue is significant: basic vocabulary topics shouldn't come after subjunctive mood and conditional sentences. Some descriptions use filler words. The interleaving is poor in the middle-to-late sections where vocabulary chapters are clustered together after heavy grammar. Overall decent content but the ordering is problematic and some chapters are borderline forbidden.

Model A has 52 chapters, which is fewer than most competitors. The progression is logical and the interleaving of grammar and vocabulary is good. Descriptions are concise. However, coverage has gaps: no chapter for hobbies/sports/leisure, no chapter for home/housing, no education chapter, no imperative mood chapter, no adverbs chapter, no possessives/demonstratives chapter, no indefinite pronouns chapter, no futur antérieur. The curriculum feels incomplete for claiming to cover A1-C2 mastery. 'Society & Politics' is borderline culture/career. The C2 content is thin (Abstract Concepts, Stylistic Inversions, Idioms & Colloquialisms). While what's there is well-done, the gaps are significant for a curriculum claiming to be 'the BEST' and 'most complete.' No chapter on causative faire. No chapter on formal register/politeness levels.

Model F has 60 chapters with reasonable coverage. The progression is logical. Grammar coverage is adequate with appropriate splits. However, there are some issues: descriptions occasionally use slightly generic phrasing. 'Scientific & Technical Discourse' and 'Rhetorical Structures' are vague. Missing some communication scenario chapters (no phone calls, no small talk, no storytelling). The vocabulary coverage is decent but missing some areas (no dedicated chapter for work/occupations which is listed in the prompt as a vocabulary theme, though this is different from career/professional chapters). No chapter for conversation management or discourse markers at the advanced level. Some chapters feel thin on description. 'Abstract Concepts' description mentions 'philosophical theories' which could border on culture/literature. Overall adequate but not as comprehensive or polished as the top models.

Model D provides an exceptionally detailed, rigorous, and highly comprehensive curriculum tailored perfectly to French. It includes advanced, uniquely French grammatical concepts with impressive granularity (e.g., specific pronoun order like 'me le lui', past participle agreement with preceding direct objects, complex relatives). It covers all CEFR levels up to C2 pragmatics (implicature, regional variations, wordplay). It strictly follows all negative constraints, avoiding fluff, skills chapters, and forbidden themes.

Model B is outstanding and nearly identical in quality to Model D. It breaks down the French language beautifully, explicitly addressing nuanced concepts like causatives with 'faire', c'est... qui/que emphasis, and sequence of tenses. The chapter titles and descriptions are incredibly concise, straight to the point, and devoid of any fluff. It fully respects the negative constraints.

Model C provides a highly extensive and accurate French curriculum. It captures core CEFR progression well, reaching advanced C2 concepts like historic usages and stylistic devices. The formatting and fluff-free guidelines are strictly adhered to. It is only slightly less granular than Models D and B regarding specific grammar mechanics, but remains an excellent output.

Model A offers a very solid and logically ordered curriculum. The titles and descriptions are perfectly concise and avoid fluff. It covers all the necessary bases for French up to the advanced levels. However, it is slightly less extensive (fewer chapters) and less granular in its breakdown of advanced grammar compared to the top three models.

Model F correctly follows the formatting rules and most constraints. However, its descriptions are slightly more generic and lack the extreme depth and linguistic precision seen in the top models. There is also a minor typo missing the circumflex on 'Être'. It successfully reaches C1/C2 levels but could be more expansive.

Model E provides a good curriculum overall but makes critical errors by violating the explicitly forbidden negative constraints. It includes a chapter on 'News & Media Language' (violating the 'NO literature or media chapters... no news media analysis' rule) and 'Formal Writing & Correspondence' (violating the 'NO skill-based chapters... no writing skills' rule). Due to the prompt's strict penalty criteria regarding forbidden topics, its score must be significantly reduced.

Strong overall coverage from beginner through mastery with clear progression and interleaving of grammar, vocabulary, and scenarios. Stays within content-domain focus and avoids explicitly forbidden chapter types (no culture/history, no exam prep, no media/literature focus, no business/career focus). French-specific grammar is handled in high granularity (clitics, agreement, subjunctive distinctions, conditionals, tense inventory including futur antérieur/conditionnel parfait, relative pronouns incl. lequel forms, discourse connectors, register, everyday spoken usage). Descriptions are mostly concise and avoid major fluff.
Minor issues: a few chapters lean toward skills/strategy framing (e.g., “High-Precision Grammar Review” feels like review/skill emphasis), but still largely grammatical content; volume is high but justified.

Excellent breadth and sequencing, with very strong advanced/C2-oriented discourse, pragmatics, focus structures, morphology, agreement edge cases, and interactional language—while generally staying inside content domains. Good chapter granularity and French-specificity (subjunctive split, causative faire, pronoun complexities, concordance of tenses).
Notable weaknesses: includes a skill-based/learning-process chapter (“Paraphrase & Synthesis”) that reads like a skills chapter rather than a language domain; “Accuracy: High-Frequency Errors,” “Style & Naturalness,” and “Near-Native Fluency” also drift into skills/coaching framing even if tied to language forms. Still no major forbidden culture/career/exam/literature content.

Solid, clean progression with good coverage of core French grammar and many key themes; avoids skill-based chapter titles and mostly avoids fluff. Includes advanced items (reported speech, passive, gerund, complex relatives, modality nuances, passé simple, idioms) and useful thematic vocabulary.
Issues: “Technology & Media” is acceptable if treated as everyday vocabulary, but “Society & Politics” can edge toward civic/culture-adjacent content (still arguably vocabulary). Some advanced chapters are niche (“Nominalization,” “Stylistic Inversions,” “Abstract Concepts”) while other practical domains are comparatively lighter (e.g., home/education not clearly present as dedicated chapters). Overall slightly less comprehensive than B/D at high levels.

Good A1–B2 core coverage with many essential grammar domains and themes; generally concise and content-focused. Includes higher-level grammar (reported speech, passive, plus-que-parfait, futur antérieur, subjunctive past, complex relatives, nominalization).
Major weakness: includes forbidden professional/career content (“Scientific & Technical Discourse”) and some descriptions lean into culturally rooted metaphors (“culturally-rooted linguistic metaphors”), which risks the no-culture rule. Also less robust C1/C2 discourse/pragmatics coverage than the top models.

Broad coverage and many strong advanced grammar/discourse chapters (information structure, register shifts, argumentation, collocations). However it directly violates forbidden topics by including “Work & Occupations” (career/professional chapter). Also includes “Formal Correspondence & Official Formulas” and “Paraphrase, Summarizing & Translation Strategies,” which veer toward skill-based/writing-focused and translation (not requested and arguably skill/process). Some titles/descriptions are slightly more academic/verbose than required.

Good general coverage and many appropriate chapters, but multiple clear violations of explicit prohibitions: includes career/professional content (“Work & Occupations,” plus negotiation/persuasion framed broadly), and includes a media chapter (“News & Media Language”), which is explicitly forbidden (media). Also includes “Formal Writing & Correspondence,” which is skill-based/writing-focused. Despite strong grammar inventory, these violations significantly reduce adherence.
